definition:
For a given nonnegative number $x$, the [*triangular number counting
function*]{} counts how many triangular numbers are not greater than
$x$. The formula is simple:
$$\lfloor \frac{-1 + \sqrt{8x + 1}}{2} \rfloor ,$$ in sharp contrast to
the lack of a formula for the prime counting function $\pi(x)$. If one
accepts 0 as a triangular number, the formula easily accommodates this
by the mere addition of 1 after flooring the fraction.

[1]{} Zhi-Wei Sun, “On Sums of Primes and Triangular Numbers” ArXiv
preprint, 10 April (2008): 1
